Introduction

Human respiratory viruses are a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, causing infection of the upper respiratory tract (eg, rhinopharyngitis) with potential lower respiratory tract (eg, bronchiolitis, pneumonia) or systemic involvement as well.  Their transmission through respiratory droplets and continuous antigenic changes make them the most concerning class of pathogens for future pandemics.

Major respiratory viruses

Classification

There are 8 categories of major human respiratory viruses:

  • Influenza viruses (A and B)
  • Coronaviruses (CoV)
  • Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)
  • Human metapneumovirus (hMPV)
  • Parainfluenza viruses (PIV 1,2, 3, and 4)
  • Rhinoviruses (RV)
  • Enteroviruses (EV D68 and A71) including Coxsackie viruses 
  • Adenoviruses (AdV)

There is no standard classification system for these viruses.  Clinically, it is customary to group the winter respiratory viruses (influenza, CoV, RSV) together.  These 3 viruses cause the majority of severe complications (eg, hospitalization) and have vaccines and antiviral therapies against key strains.

Antigenic diversity

Respiratory viruses undergo constant genetic change through 2 mechanisms:

  • Antigenic drift:  Continuous accumulation of mutations causing progressive change in viral proteins.  All viruses slowly drift, gradually escaping adaptive immune recognition and making long-lasting immunization impossible (ie, "there is no cure for the common cold").
  • Antigenic shift:  Discrete events in which viral genomes undergo reassortment (
    figure 1
    ) or recombination (
    figure 2
    ) when 2 viral strains infect the same cell.  This is particularly important for influenza A where the hemagglutinin (H) and neuraminidase (N) proteins reassort, producing new virulent strains such as swine flu (H1N1) and bird flu (H5N1).

Pathogenesis

All of these viruses have the common features of transmission primarily via respiratory droplets (>100 microns, fall with gravity) and aerosols (<10 microns, stay suspended).  Fomites (eg, contaminated surfaces such as door handles) are a secondary source.  On entry, the viruses fuse to and enter upper respiratory epithelial cells (eg, nasopharyngeal mucosa) via specific surface receptors (eg, influenza hemagglutinin binds to sialic acid; RSV F protein binds to nAChR).

Once the virus is intracellular, a cytotoxic immune response is activated (eg, interferons, interleukins, CD8+ and NK cells, apoptosis).  Some viruses also induce direct cytopathic effects (eg, RSV creates intercellular syncytia, influenza budding causes membrane lysis) resulting in cell death.  The resulting tissue damage and inflammation coincide with onset of clinical symptoms (eg, congestion, pharyngitis) and generally correspond to PCR positivity.

Specific manifestations

All major respiratory viruses produce a similar upper respiratory syndrome (eg, congestion, coryza, cough, varying systemic symptoms).  In addition to these nonspecific aspects, certain clinical features distinguish the viruses:

Influenza virus

Influenza (ie, flu) typically features a milder upper respiratory component (eg, less cough and rhinitis) but more severe systemic symptoms such as high fever, headache, intense malaise, and pronounced myalgias.  Certain populations (eg, elderly, pregnant, chronic medical conditions, nursing home residents) are at high risk of morbidity and mortality.  Death is usually not due to primary influenza infection itself but from secondary bacterial pneumonia (eg, initial improvement followed by sudden worsening).

Coronaviruses

These are divided into 2 categories.  The pandemic severe acute respiratory syndrome viruses (SARS-CoV, SARS-CoV2, and MERS-CoV) are more likely to cause severe viral pneumonia, which can progress to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and multiorgan failure.  The endemic coronaviruses (eg, CoV2 OC43, 229E, and NL63) mainly cause a milder illness (ie, common cold).

RSV

This is the main cause of bronchiolitis in infants and children (age <2) and a major risk factor for later development of asthma.  RSV bronchiolitis (

) involves an upper respiratory prodrome followed by small airway obstruction (eg, wheezing, hyperinflation, retractions).  RSV is also a major cause of severe morbidity in adults with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) (eg, acute exacerbation).

Human metapneumovirus

This is taxonomically related to RSV and is an emerging cause of severe bronchiolitis and pneumonia in high-risk populations (especially elderly, immunocompromised, and chronic lung disease).  Because its prevalence is rising, human metapneumovirus is increasingly recognized as the fourth winter respiratory virus (together with influenza, RSV, and CoV).

Parainfluenza

This is the main cause of croup (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
) (ie, laryngotracheitis) in infants and children (6 months-3 years).  Parainfluenza infection causes glottic edema, producing inspiratory stridor, a hoarse barking ("croupy") cough (
figure 3
), and potentially severe narrowing of the upper airway (eg, steeple sign (
figure 4
)) on neck x-ray).

Rhinoviruses

These are the most common cause of the common cold overall (~40%).  RV tends to produce mild symptoms but is a frequent cause of acute exacerbations of asthma and COPD.

Enteroviruses

The nonpolio enteroviruses (mainly EV-D68 and A71) typically cause a common cold syndrome, but rarely produce neurologic infection (eg, aseptic meningitis, encephalitis, acute flaccid myelitis).  Contrary to their name, fecal-oral spread and gastroenteritis are minor secondary features.  Coxsackieviruses are a subgroup of EV that cause herpangina (posterior oropharyngeal vesicles), hand-foot-mouth disease (herpangina + palm and sole lesions), pleuritis, and myopericarditis.

Adenoviruses

These viruses cause common cold with conjunctivitis (ie, pink eye), sometimes called pharyngoconjunctival fever.  Other potential manifestations include pneumonia (eg, immunocompromised) and gastroenteritis (eg, fecal-oral transmission and tropism to Peye's patches).

Diagnosis and management

For rapid diagnosis, multiplex PCR testing (ie, respiratory viral panel) is now widely available at point of care, detecting all major respiratory viruses with excellent sensitivity and specificity.  Home antigen-based testing is available for influenza and SARS-CoV2 (lower sensitivity than PCR).

In practice, the main decision is whether to provide antiviral treatment.

  • Influenza:  Oseltamivir and zanamivir are neuraminidase inhibitors (
    figure 5
    ) that prevent viral release.  They are indicated for high-risk populations (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
    ) and can be given prophylactically (ie, within 48 hours of exposure, 10-day course) or therapeutically (ie, within 48 hours of symptom onset, 5-day course). 
  • SARS-CoV2:  Nirmatrelvir/ritonavir is a boosted protease inhibitor that prevents proviral peptide cleavage.  It is indicated for mild-to-moderate (ie, outpatient) COVID-19 in patients with risk factors for progression to severe disease (eg, age â‰¥65, obesity, chronic medical conditions, immunosuppressed). 
  • RSV:  Nirsevimab is a monoclonal antibody against the fusion protein, preventing cell entry.  Because it is an immune globulin that neutralizes the virus extracellularly, it is also considered a form of passive immunization.  It is indicated for neonates and infants with risk factors for severe RSV bronchiolitis (eg, preterm birth, bronchopulmonary dysplasia, congenital heart disease).

All viral respiratory infections are managed with supportive care (eg, hydration, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, sinus rinses).  Acute exacerbations of underlying asthma or COPD require standard interventions (eg, bronchodilators, systemic corticosteroids).  Severe croup (eg, stridor at rest) is treated with humidified air, systemic corticosteroids, and nebulized epinephrine.

Prevention involves social distancing and self-quarantine, hygiene practices (eg, hand washing >20 seconds with soap and water, avoiding hand-to-face contact), personal protective equipment (eg, face masks), and vaccination (influenza (

), RSV, SARS-CoV2).

Differential diagnosis

Bacterial upper respiratory tract infections

Viral upper respiratory tract infections involve pharyngitis due to direct infection and postnasal drainage.  However, serious bacterial upper airway infections can have a similar picture, typically with severe throat pain as their central feature:

  • Epiglottitis:  Mainly caused Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus, and Haemophilus influenzae (type B) (now uncommon with HiB vaccine).  Epiglottitis causes inspiratory stridor akin to viral croup.  However, unlike croup, patients appear acutely toxic (eg, very high fever), have severe throat pain, and have very rapid worsening of upper airway obstruction.  Specific features of epiglottitis include drooling, muffled voice, respiratory distress, and thumb (or thumbprint) sign (
    figure 6
    ) on lateral neck x-ray.
  • Streptococcal pharyngitis:  Caused by Streptococcus pyogenes.  Patients typically present with pharyngitis as the dominant symptom in the background of an influenza-like illness (headache, myalgias, malaise).  Like influenza, cough is relatively absent.  However, purulent pharyngeal exudates and prominent cervical adenopathy are typically present.
  • Diphtheria:  Caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.  Patients have severe throat pain and a grayish, thick, fibrinous pseudomembrane adherent to the posterior pharynx and tonsils.  The pseudomembrane can cause airway obstruction and asphyxiation. 

Bacterial community-acquired pneumonia

Community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) is defined as an new pulmonary infiltrate in the setting of compatible lower respiratory symptoms (eg, fever, chest pain, purulent sputum).  Roughly 70% of CAP cases are bacterial and 30% are viral (mainly influenza, hMPV, and adenovirus).

Distinguishing viral from bacterial CAP is important as part of the effort to promote appropriate antibiotic use (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 5
) and prevent bacterial resistance.  This is very difficult (and usually impossible) on initial presentation based on clinical data alone.  Although viral pneumonia classically produces diffuse interstitial infiltrates, it can also cause dense focal consolidation (like typical bacterial lobar pneumonia).  The host systemic inflammatory response (eg, fever, neutrophilic leukocytosis) is also similar, although fever and leukocytosis are generally higher with bacterial infection.  A true secondary bacterial pneumonia can develop in ~20% of patients with influenza (eg, initial improvement followed by recurrence of fever and development of productive cough) or COVID-19, further complicating the picture.

Procalcitonin (PCT) is an acute phase reactant selectively released during bacterial (eg, induced by tumor necrosis factor-É‘) more so than viral (eg, not induced by interferon-É‘/êžµ) infections.  Serum PCT effectively discriminates between bacterial (eg, PCT >0.5 ng/mL) and viral (eg, PCT <0.1 ng/mL) lower respiratory tract infections.  It is increasingly used in hospital settings but typically takes some time to result.  It is used to guide early discontinuation of empiric antibiotics for CAP, rather than the decision to start or withhold them.

Other respiratory viruses

Several rarer viruses can cause potentially severe lower respiratory and multisystem involvement:

Hantavirus 

Spread by particulates from rodent feces, particularly in rural areas of the southwestern United States, hantavirus infection begins with a gastrointestinal prodrome (eg, abdominal pain, nausea) with relatively minimal upper respiratory symptoms except for cough.  However, it can rapidly progress to ARDS, circulatory failure, and hemorrhagic fever.  Florid capillary leak (eg, marked hemoconcentration), thrombocytopenia, and copious bronchorrhea are distinctive characteristics.  Diagnosis involves IgM serology.  Treatment is supportive, and patients should be referred to a tertiary extracorporeal membrane oxygenation-enabled care center if possible.

Rubeola (measles)

Spread by respiratory droplets (extremely contagious) among children in congregate settings (eg, daycare), measles typically presents with an upper respiratory prodrome consisting of "3Cs":  coryza, cough, and conjunctivitis.  Koplik spots (small, grainlike, white buccal pustules) are a specific sign.  Later, a diffuse exanthem (morbilliform eruption) appears.  Complications include encephalitis and pneumonia.  Diagnosis involves IgM serology.  Treatment is supportive, with vitamin A given in severe cases (helps to maintain mucosal integrity).

Parvovirus B19

Spread by respiratory droplet (and vertical) transmission, parvovirus (fifth disease or erythema infectiosum) presents with a nonspecific upper respiratory prodrome and "slapped-cheek" appearance of facial erythema.  In children, it can potentially cause aplastic anemia in patients with chronic hemolysis (eg, thalassemia).  It is the most closely linked virus to seronegative reactive arthritis.

Summary

Human respiratory viruses affect the upper and possibly lower respiratory tract, potentially leading to serious complications such as pneumonia and exacerbations of chronic heart and lung conditions (eg, asthma).  There are 8 major categories, with the winter respiratory viruses (influenza, coronaviruses, and RSV) constituting the bulk of morbidity and mortality.  Clinical manifestations often overlap, presenting with upper respiratory symptoms (ie, rhinopharyngitis); however, specific viruses can lead to distinct severe conditions (eg, croup with parainfluenza, bronchiolitis with RSV).

Rapid diagnosis with multiplex PCR testing (ie, respiratory viral panel) is widely used.  Antiviral treatments are available for some viruses (influenza, SARS-CoV2, and RSV), while supportive care is the cornerstone of management.  Preventive measures such as vaccination, hygiene practices, and social distancing are vital to reduce transmission risks.
